The geometryLib API reference¶

Routines for working with triangles.

The modules inside of this package are picked with useful features for the programmer who needs to support triangles:

shape
This module provides a full-fledged Triangle object that can be instantiated and then asked to provide all sorts of information about its properties.
utils
For the programmer in a hurry, this module offers quick functions that take as arguments the three side lengths of a triangle, and performs a quick conputation without the programmer having to make the extra step of creating an object

The “shape” module¶

Use the triangle class to represent triangles

class geometrylib.shape.Triangle(a, b, c)[source]¶

Triangles are three sided polygons

area()[source]¶

Return the area of the triangle

is_equilateral()[source]¶

Return wether this triangle is equilateral

is_isosceles()[source]¶

Return wether this triangle is isosceles

is_similar(triangle)[source]¶

Return wether this triangle is similar to another

perimeter()[source]¶

Return the perimeter of the triangle

scale(factor)[source]¶

Return a new triangle, ‘factor’ times the size of this one

The “utils” module¶

Routines to test triangle properties without explicit instantiation.

geometrylib.utils.compute_area(a, b, c)[source]¶

Return the area of the triangle with side lengths a, b and c.

If the three lengths provided cannot form a triangle, then the area 0 is returned.

geometrylib.utils.compute_perimiter(a, b, c)[source]¶

Return the perimeter of the triangle with side lengths a, b and c.

If the three lengths provided cannot form a triangle, then the perimeter 0 is returned.

geometrylib.utils.is_equilateral(a, b, c)[source]¶

Return whether lengths a, b and c are an equilateral triangle.

geometrylib.utils.is_isosceles(a, b, c)[source]¶

Return whether lengths a, b and c are an isosceles triangle.

geometrylib.utils.is_triangle(a, b, c)[source]¶

Test whether lengths a, b and c can be the sides of a triangle.
